tit.e: Kenminsen (envoy ships dispatched to Ming China)
Kenminsen (envoy ships dispatched to Ming China)
tit.cmt: 以下説明が続くので、英語説明を削除しました。

sen.j: 遣明船（けんみんせん）は室町時代の応永11年（1404年）から天文 (元号)16年（1547年）まで約1世紀半で17次（のべ84隻）に渡り、日明貿易（勘合貿易）に用いられた船のことである。
sen.e: Kenminsen means ships dispatched to Ming China in the Muromachi period for 17 times (the total number of ships was 84) during the period of one and a half centuries from 1404 to 1547 for the purpose of Nichi-Ming trade (the trade between Japan and the Ming Dynasty, China) (Kango trade).

Kenminsen means ships dispatched seventeen times to Ming China in the Muromachi period seventeen times (the total number of ships was eighty-four) during the period of one and a half centuries from 1404 to 1547 for the purpose of Nichi-Ming trade (trade between Japan and the Ming Dynasty, China) (Kango trade).

Kenminsen means ships dispatched seventeen times to Ming China in the Muromachi period (the total number of ships was eighty-four) during the period of one and a half centuries from 1404 to 1547 for the purpose of Nichi-Ming trade (trade between Japan and the Ming Dynasty, China) (Kango trade).

sen.j: 日明貿易には、両国により正式の渡航船であることを証明する勘合符が用いられたことから、勘合船とも呼ばれた。
sen.e: These ships were also called Kangosen since both government issued a certificate called Kangofu in order to prove the visiting ships were lawfully registered ships for Nichi-Ming trade.

sen.j: 足利義満は、応永8年（1401年）に僧の祖阿と博多商人の肥富を派遣し、明との交易を申し入れ、明の使者から「永楽の勘合符」を得て、勘合貿易が始まる。
sen.e: Kango trade started in 1401 when Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA proposed to start the trade with Ming by dispatching a Buddhist monk Soa and a merchant in Hakata Koitomi and received "Eiraku kangofu" from the envoy of Ming.

sen.j: 遣明船は当初、幕府が直接船主となり運航していた。
sen.e: Originally, bakufu was the shipowner of Kenminsen and directly operated them.

sen.j: 幕府の力がしだいに弱まるようになると有力寺社（相国寺、三十三間堂など）や有力守護大名（細川氏、大内氏など）が船主となり、これに博多や堺の商人、瀬戸内海の町、水夫が結びついて貿易を行った。
sen.e: With the power of bakufu gradually declined, influential temples/shrines (Shoku-ji Temple, Sanjusangendo Temple etc) or influential shogo-daimyo (territorial lords as provincial constables) (the Hosokawa clan, the Ouchi clan etc.) became the shipowners and did trade in corporation with merchants in Hakata and Sakai as well as sailors in the towns located in the coastal region of Seto Inland Sea.

sen.j: 最終的には貿易の主導権を巡り細川氏と大内氏は争い、大永3年（1523年）には寧波で衝突（寧波の乱）し、大内氏は貿易を独占することになる。
sen.e: The Hosokawa clan and Ouchi clan competed for seizing the initiative of trade, clashed at Neiha in 1523 and finally the Ouchi clan monopolized the trade.

sen.j: 結果、大内氏の本拠である山口は応仁の乱で荒廃した京都よりはるかに繁栄することとなった。
sen.e: As a result, Yamaguch, the base of the Ouchi clan, prospered far more than Kyoto that was devastated by the Onin War.

sen.j: 1406年に帰国した第二次遣明船は6～7隻と記録が残っており、1410に足利義持が中止するまでの初期6回の遣明船の船団規模は同程度であったと推定される。
sen.e: As the record is existent that the number of ships of second Kenminsen fleet returned to Japan in ? was 6 to 7, it is presumed that the scale of six Kenminsen fleets which visited Ming until Yoshimochi ASHIKAGA ceased dispatching in ? was in the same range.

sen.j: 21年の中断を経て、足利義教が1432に再開し、1550までに11次51隻（このうち、幕府所有船は7隻で、朝廷船1隻、残りは守護大名、寺社所有船であった）が渡航している。

sen.j: 1468に足利義政の命令で明に渡った禅僧の天与清啓が記録した『戊子入明記』によると、遣明船は700～1700石の大型船で150人程度の乗員（内水夫50人）であった。
sen.e: According to "Boshi Nyuminki " written by Zen monk Tenyo Seikei, who visited Ming in ? at the behest of Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA, large ships, whose size were 700 to 1700 goku (a unit of ship size), were used for Kenminsen and 150 persons (including 50 sailors) were on board.

sen.j: 遣明船は、季節風を利用して航海を行った。
sen.e: Kenminsen sailed using seasonal winds.

sen.j: 春又は秋の東北の季節風に乗って大陸へ渡り、5月以降、西南西の季節風に乗り、日本へ帰国した。
sen.e: Ships left for the Asian continent in Spring or Autumn using a northeast seasonal wind and returned to Japan after May using a west-southwest seasonal wind.

sen.j: 宋 (王朝)代には磁鉄鉱から永久磁石を作るようになり、羅針盤の発見も済んでおり、永正の航海書にも「磁石の針」との言及があることから、遣明船は原始的コンパスを利用した航海を行っていたと考えられる。
sen.e: Judging from the fact that the production of permanent magnet made of magnetite began in the age of the Sung dynasty, compass was already invented by that time and the term "magnetic pointer" is seen in the navigation book written in the Eisho era, it is considered that Kenminsen sailed using primitive compass.

sen.j: 航路は堺、兵庫から瀬戸内海を通り、下関、博多を経由し東シナ海を直線的に横断して寧波を目指した。
sen.e: Staring from Sakai or Hyogo, Kenminsen passed Seto Inland Sea, stopped at Shimonoseki or Hakata and sailed for Neiha by traversing the East China Sea in a linear fashion.

sen.j: 細川氏と大内氏の対立が深まると、細川氏は大内氏の山口の側を通る瀬戸内航路を避け、土佐の浦戸、下田、南九州の油津、坊津を経由して寧波に行く航路をとった。
sen.e: When the confrontation between the Hosokawa clan and Ouchi clan became serious, the Hosokawa clan avoided to take the route of Seto Inland Sea which passed near Yamaguchi, the base of the Ouchi clan, and instead took the route to sail for Neiha via Urado and Shimoda in Tosa Province and Aburatsu and Bonotsu in southern Kyushu.

sen.j: 遣明船は遣唐使船と異なり、専用船を新造したわけではなく、国内の民間の廻船（商船）の借り入れた。
sen.e: Unlike the case of Kentoshisen (envoy ships dispatched to Tang, China), ships of Kenminsen were not the ones that were newly built for exclusive use but the rented private ships (merchant ships).

sen.j: 遣明船として遠洋航海用に艤装品を充実させ、外交使節や有力商人などの居室用の屋形を増設するなど大規模改修を行って用いた。
sen.e: These rented ships were used for Kenminsen after conducting major renovation such as the installation of hull fittings suitable for ocean navigation and the expansion of cabins for diplomatic envoys or influential merchants.

sen.j: 船体構造は木を刳（く）り貫いて造られる航（かわら：船底部）の部材（刳船部材）を板材に置き換え、両角に重木（おもき）というL型の丈夫な部材を用い、数枚の棚板を重ね継ぎして、多数の船梁（ふなばり）で補強した、棚板造りの構造であった。
sen.e: The structure of hull was Tanaita (shelf boards) structure using sawn timber as the component of Kawara (the components for the bottom of a ship), instead of the ones hollowed from a tree trunk, L-shaped strong components called Omoki for both sides and several layered Tanaita reinforced by many Funabari (beams fitted horizontally between the planks on the hull of a ship for preventing water pressure).

sen.j: 棚板構成は、根棚・中棚・上棚の三階造りと中棚のない二階造りが基本となり、大型船では中棚を二段にした四階造りのものも存在した。
sen.e: Basic structure of Tanaita was either three layered structure consists of Nedana (the components to structure the lowest part of a ship), Chudana (the components to structure the middle part of a ship) and Uedana (the components to structure the upper part of a ship) or two layered structure without Chudana and in the case of large ships, four layered structure with two layered Chudana was also seen.
